block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews from the 1920's and 30's. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' music tonight from 5:45 to 8, with Mark Whitfield Quartet. Free with admission; food and cash bar. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through Sept. 23. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. Crafts market, with more than 100 dealers from the metropolitan area selling antiques, collectibles and hand-crafted items, Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $1; 50 cents for children. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the city's history. Sunday at 1 p.m., a tribute to Jenny Lind, ''The Swedish Nightingale,'' featuring a concert by Charlotte Philley and Deborah Saverance, and a lecture by F. Paul Driscoll, managing editor of Opera News, examining Jenny Lind's career; call Extension 257 for reservations. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' through Oct. 15. ''New York: Songs of the City,'' through Sunday. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

NATIONAL MUSEUM OF THE AMERICAN INDIAN, Alexander Hamilton United States Customs House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., discussions and demonstrations by Quichua weavers, Continuing exhibitions: ''All Roads Are Good: Native Voices on Life and Culture,'' presenting more than 300 objects from the museum's collection chosen by 23 American Indians, and ''Creation's Journey: Masterworks of Native American Identity and Belief.'' Daily screenings in the video viewing room begin at 1 p.m. and are repeated on Thursdays at 5:30 p.m. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 514-3888.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, and photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; on view through Oct. 1. ''Jenny Lind: The Swedish Nightingale in America,'' through Oct. 29. Opening Tuesday, ''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert (1859-1934).'' Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.

SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. Monday at 6 p.m. in the Whitman Gallery, 209 Water Street, ''Performance: Jenny Lind in Castle Garden,'' a concert with Ellen Young, soprano, and Carol Binkowski, pianist, featuring songs, historical anecdotes and slides commemorating the 150th anniversary of the singer's American debut at Castle Garden. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; until 8 p.m. Tuesday. Stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Museum admission: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 748-8600; reservations for special events: (212) 748-8786; the marketplace, (212) 732-7678.
Gardens

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. Sunday from 6 to 10 p.m., ''Autumn Moon Festival'' in the Chinese Scholar's Garden, featuring a tea ceremony with Moon Cake, Chinese Folk Dance Ensemble, lion dancing and lantern making. Admission: $5; $4 for students, children under 12 and the elderly. ''China: Ancient Art and Sciences,'' featuring 13 artisans from China demonstrating their craft and 300 works of art; through Oct. 1. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden: $7.50; $5 for the elderly and students and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.

WAVE HILL, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. Gardens, greenhouses and woodlands are part of the 28-acre garden and cultural institution. ''Beneath the Bark, Under Leaf and Log,'' an outdoor installation by Sylvia Benitez; through Oct. 30. Saturdays at 10 a.m., beginners; 11 a.m. intermediates, programs of Tai Chi; $7. Saturdays from 1 to 4 p.m. through Oct. 28, visitors can work along foresters to prune, plant and clear excess vegetation. Tuesdays through Sundays, 9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.
Zoos

BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Some 265 wooded acres are devoted to naturalistic habitats, including Jungle World, African Plains, the Baboon Reserve, the World of Birds, the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 p.m.), Big Birds and the Congo Gorilla Forest (Admission: $3 when the gorillas are outside depending on the weather) The Butterfly Zone is open through Oct. 1, depending on the weather, with thousands of butterflies and moths and an area where visitors can see the metamorphosis of chrysalides, or cocoons, into butterflies or moths, weather permitting (Admission: $2). Through Sept. 30, daily tours; reservations necessary: (718) 220-5141. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. General admission, $9; $5 for children 2 to 12 and the elderly; free general admission for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.

PROSPECT PARK ZOO, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. Geared to children, with sea lions, wallabies, baboons, farm animals and a discovery trail. Tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m., activitities at the zoo will focus on how young animals learn to survive in the wild. Sea lion feedings daily at 11:30 a.m., 2 and 4 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; weekends, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.
Cruises

ADIRONDACK, leaving from Chelsea Piers Sports and Entertainment Complex, 23rd Street on the Hudson River. An 80-foot schooner that goes on two-hour sails daily around New York Harbor at 10:30 a.m., 1, 3:30, 6 and 9 p.m. Tickets: weekdays, $30 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $40, and includes drinks; weekends, $35 for all sails except the 6 and 9 p.m. sail, which is $45, including drinks. Information: (800) 701-7245.

CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42nd Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A two-hour, 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations, daily at 11 a.m., 2 p.m. and 4:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour, 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan, daily at 9:30, 10:15 and 11:45 a.m., 12:30, 1:15, 2:45 and 3:30 p.m. Tickets: $24; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. ''Harbor Lights,'' daily at 7 p.m. Tickets: $20; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. ''The Beast,'' 30-minute speedboat ride in the harbor, daily, every hour on the hour, 11 a.m. to dusk, except Wednesdays, when it is 2 p.m. to dusk. Tickets: $15; children 5 to 12, $10. Information: (212) 563-3200.

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.
RECREATION

''CONTINENTAL AIRLINES BROADWAY ON BROADWAY RUN.'' Central Park. A 2.5 mile run on Sunday at 9:30 a.m. Runners will raise funds for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race day registration fee, $22; $15 for club members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.
EVENTS

''A CLOSE LOOK AT CHINA,'' Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, West 34th Street, at 11th Avenue, Manhattan. A display of art and fashion. Today through Sunday, noon to 8 p.m. Through Sept. 15. Free. Information: (877) 772-5673.

''BLUES IN THE NIGHT,'' Chelsea Piers, Pier 62, Hudson River and 23rd Street. Last concert in the monthly Rivermusic Festival. Tomorrow at 6 p.m. Tickets, $10; free for children under 16. Information: (212) 336-6881.

''E-SHOW: THE CONSUMER INTERNET EVENT,'' Madison Square Garden. A two-day event featuring exhibits, demonstrations and workshops offered by more than 150 companies that advertise over the Internet. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 7 a.m.; and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission, $12 ($20 for two days). Information: (212) 307-7171.

''ART YARD SALE,'' N.Y.C. Lab School, 333 West 17th Street, Chelsea. More than 60 artists will display and sell their work. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission, $5; proceeds will benefit the N.Y.C. Lab School. Information: (212) 243-5050.

''POETRY IN PUBLIC PLACES,'' Blue Heron Park, Nature Center, Poillon Avenue, between Highland Boulevard and Amboy Road, Annandale, Staten Island. Features a free reading by Galway Kinnell. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. Sponsored by the Poetry Society of America. Information: (718) 967-3542.

''LABOR DAY: WORKING WORDS AND IMAGES,'' Eldridge Street Project, 12 Eldridge Street, Lower Manhattan. A photography display, panel discussion and musical presentation devoted to issues regarding the Jewish labor movement in New York. Sunday at 2 p.m. Admission, $6; $4 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 219-0903.

BROADWAY ON BROADWAY, Times Square. Performances by casts of Broadway musicals. Sunday, noon to 2 p.m. Sponsored by the Times Square Business Improvement District and the League of American Theaters and Producers.

''FORGET-ME-NOT BRUNCH,'' Regency Hotel, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street. An event for grandparents and their grandchildren or friends. Menu prices range from $18 to $35, $10 for children; proceeds benefit the Alzheimer's Association and the National Grandparents' Day Council. Sunday, from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Information and reservations: (212) 339-4050.
ON THE STREET
FULTON STREET FOLLIES, Fulton Street from William to Water Streets. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the South Bridge Senior Citizens Center.
WASHINGTON SQUARE OUTDOOR ART EXHIBIT, streets surrounding Washington Square Park in Greenwich Village. Tomorrow and Sunday, noon to 6 p.m.
LABOR DAY PARADE, Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 72nd Streets, dispersing at Third Avenue, Manhattan. Tomorrow at 10:30 a.m.

ONE WORLD FESTIVAL 2000, East 35th Street, between First and Second Avenues, Manhattan. Music, dance, crafts and food. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. and Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America.
2000 THIRD AVENUE COMMUNITY BENEFIT STREET FAIR, from 66th to 86th Streets, Manhattan. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Sponsored by the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce.
13TH UPPER BROADWAY FALL MUSIC FESTIVAL, Broadway, 96th to 110th Street. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the West Side One Stop for Coordinated Senior Services.
15TH INTERNATIONAL CULTURES PARADE AND CELEBRATION, Madison Avenue, between 23rd and 42nd Street. Sunday at 3 p.m. Sponsored by the International Immigrants Foundation.
WALKING TOURS

''SOUTH STREET SEAPORT/DUTCH ORIGINS OF NEW YORK,'' from South Ferry to the South Street Seaport, Lower Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday at 11:45 a.m. and 2:15 p.m. Fee, $11. Sponsored by Gotham Walk. Reservations: (212) 629-1886.

''FIFTH AVENUE GOLD COAST,'' Upper East Side. Explore the mansions to the east of Central Park, including the Henry Clay Frick Mansion, the James B. Duke Mansion and the Edward S. Harkness House. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

GREENWICH VILLAGE. A free tour that covers sites associated with Edward Hopper, Andy Warhol, Lou Reed, Jimi Hendrix, Jack Kerouac and Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney. Meets tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. from the northwest corner of Second Avenue and St. Marks Place. Sponsored by the Village Alliance. Information: ( 212) 777-2173.

''REVOLUTIONARY MANHATTAN: A CITY OF 26,000,'' Lower Manhattan. A discussion about the area as it appeared in 1776. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. on the northwest corner of State and Whitehall Streets. Fee, $15. Sponsored by Century Walking Tours. Information: (201) 433-0946.

WALKING TOUR OF JAMAICA, Queens, traces the development of the area from its roots as an agricultural community. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at King Manor Museum, Jamaica Avenue, between 150th and 153rd Streets. Fee, $5. Sponsored by the King Manor Museum. Information: (718) 206-0545.

''HISTORIC HARLEM.'' With stops at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, Striver's Row and sites associated with Zora Neale Hurston and Langston Hughes. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. in front of the Schomburg Center, at the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''LIGHTS! ACTION! CAMERA!'' visits sites of prominence in films like ''Ghostbusters II,'' ''North by Northwest,'' ''Carlito's Way'' and ''Conspiracy Theory.'' Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. on the southwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Fee, $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

WAVE HILL AND RIVERDALE AND INWOOD PARKS. A five-mile walk in the Bronx and upper Manhattan. Meets tomorrow at 10:30 a.m. at the 242nd Street entrance to Van Cortlandt Park. Fee, $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club and the New York Hiking Club. Information: (212) 246-9593.

''MORE THAN A TREE GROWS IN BROOKLYN: THE BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN AND PROSPECT PARK,'' visits the two outdoor gems with a stop for a picnic lunch. Sunday at 10 a.m. Fee, $25. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Information and reservations: (212) 996-1100.

''DOWNTOWN DECO: DEVELOPMENT AND DECORATION IN THE JAZZ AGE,'' Lower Manhattan. How Art Deco and modern office buildings have coexisted in the area, with stops at 1 Wall Street and the Downtown Athletic Club. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the southwest corner of Fulton and Williams Streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''THE ONCE AND FUTURE CONEY ISLAND'' covers the evolution of this landmark with a stop for lunch. Meets Sunday at 10 a.m. on the corner of Stillwell and Surf Avenues. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for Center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, Extension 401.
